newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Queensland Cotton sees profit maintained.
newsitem.headline: Queensland Cotton sees profit maintained.

text.p: Cotton ginner and marketer Queensland Cotton Holdings Ltd said it expected to maintain profitability in the current year ended February, 1998.
"I'm very positive about our outlook. I expect we can maintain the level of profitability in the current year," Queensland Cotton chief executive Richard Haire told Reuters.
He said he was optimistic about the 1997 New South Wales crop and expected Queensland to maintain last year's production.
"All the growth is coming out of New South Wales which recovered from the drought quicker than Queensland growers," Haire said.
Queensland Cotton earlier reported a record net profit of A$13.26 million for the year ended February 28, 1997 compared with an $8.03 million net profit previously.
Haire said the crop in Queensland currently being picked would be about the same as last season.
He said Queensland Cotton was positive about continuing use of transgenic pest resistant cotton seed despite early criticism of its effectiveness by farmers.
"An analysis in mid-February showed the new strains had led to a 68 percent drop in insecticide use," Haire said.
Haire said farmers had been critical of the seed's effectiveness against insects because of early high expectations for the new strain.
"Transgenic seed is critical but it is only a part of crop management," he said.
"The cotton crop has to be managed well but we are continuing to finesse the technology," he said.
He said cotton prices were currently low and were expected to remain depressed for some time while there was an overhang in world stocks.
"I can't see any reason to be over-bullish about prices," Haire said.
Queensland Cotton was keen to expand its business "but nothing in the way of acquisitions is in sight at present," he said.
"However, there is a lot of interest by the United States in the Australian cotton industry," he said.
